fields.description:
About half the time, I see a "stop script?" dialog when pulling up policy wizard. Pretty much all the time, the page loads way too slowly. 

There must be something better we can do to improve loading this page. It's unacceptably slow.

Maybe not front-load so much stuff, load hidden items as they are required for view? Defer loading things until associated accordions are opened perhaps? Especially defer loading of the "Advanced" stuff until it's needed...
fields.summary: IAM Policy Generator page loads too slowly

comments.body: Note that I'm able to reproduce this only when I have Firebug or Web Inspector open (and with cache disabled) while loading the page.  Without web inspector, and with the cache enabled, the page consistently loads in under 5 seconds, using a VPN connection to the CLC host.  Also, enabling the Pyramid Debug Toolbar slows the page considerably, probably due to the sheer volume of DOM nodes required to build the page.

[~jloza], [~kgill]: I reproduced this using IE over a VPN connection.  In this case however, the policies never loaded.   The left side of the screen loaded showing the selection of polices but the right side that shows details of the policy selected never loads.  I am unable to even save a policy using IE because the button to create the policies never loads.  I will attach a screenshot that shows the behavior.

Pull request at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1166

Heads up for [~jloza]: Be sure to review the page without using the Web Inspector, Chrome's Dev Tools, or Firebug, since the IAM policy wizard will take an order of magnitude longer to load with those open due to the sheer number of DOM elements on that page.  

Testing across Safari, Chrome and Firefox on Mac OS 10.8.5, I'm seeing load times of 4-5 seconds across the board with the browser cache disabled, and 2-3 seconds with cache enabled (testing on Safari 6.2).  The load times for Firefox are slightly longer than Safari.  Chrome continues to be fairly slow (sometimes taking almost 10 seconds to load), but I'm not seeing any stop script warnings there.  Hopefully future versions of Chrome will continue to optimize for Angular, especially since both those projects are run by Google.
passing this on for code review. This still seems too slow, but if this is the best we can do for 4.1, we can revisit in 4.2.

Purely based on timing, I would not merge this since it is roughly 3 seconds slower from pressing "add access policy" to page being rendered. I haven't looked at the code, but considering the outward performance, it isn't ready.

[~dkavanagh]: Could you elaborate on the timing measurements.  What did you use to measure the page load time?  And on what browser?  

I used the AngularJS extension for Chrome (a.k.a. Batarang) and optimized the page by removing the most expensive call listed by Batarang, namely the getConditionType() calls from the template.
[~dkavanagh]: One possible explanation for the increased load time is the switch from jquery-datetimepicker (which isn't CSP compatible) to a Foundation-based date picker.

I was on FF with OS X. I used a hand-held stop watch and did 4 times for develop and 4 for this branch. I forced javascript reload between tests to ensure I was testing the proper code. 
For develop, I saw 10-11 seconds. For this branch, I saw 13-14 seconds.

this PR fixes something that's broken (condition inputs don't work properly) but slows the load even further. 

Fixing this PR properly means refactoring the dialog entirely. Too much work for 4.1, so let's target a bug for 4.2 and get this fixed then, and merge this one now to fix the broken stuff.
Advising we merge the PR since it includes fixes for various "Add Condition" inputs such as the datetime input.
Going to try to optimize further
Tweaked the timeout, but since most of the loading time is spent rendering the DOM, there isn't much more we can do here w/o completely refactoring the policy generator.
